In 8/8 time there are 72 eighth notes per quarter note or 112 eighth notes per half note. If the eighth notes are combined with the whole and/or half notes they're grouped with, the total number of measures is lower: The combination of a whole note and two eighth notes last 2/8 of a measure; the combination of a half note and two eighth notes last 1/8 of a measure. These don't affect timing significantly, as the number of whole notes and their rests within a measure remain the same. Although it does depend on how the piece is performed, if these rests are "rubatoed" (i.e., slightly expanded/reduced), these notes may end up occupying 3 measures depending on how the performer chooses to emphasize them.

Note: the eighth note, quarter note, and whole note note durations are presumed to each be divisible by the beat duration, except where otherwise indicated by a dot.
Tempo: the tempo duration is presumed to be a duration divisible by the beat duration, and the beats are presumed to be evenly durated unless otherwise indicated by a dot.
The duration of a quarter note is a duration divisible by 2 in the given time signature, so the half note duration must be twice the duration of a quarter note, and the whole note duration must be 2*3=6 times the duration of a quarter note, leaving another half note to take up 2 measures, and the sixteenth note duration must be 6/3=2 times the duration of a quarter note.

The dot can indicate that the duration of a beat, or note, takes up an uneven number of beats, for example:
* In 2/2 time the duration of a half note can be indicated as dotted, meaning that it takes up 3 beats.
* In 3/4 time the duration of a dotted quarter note can be indicated as taking up 3 beats.

The use of the dot can clarify a complex rhythm or indicate an off beat in a complex time signature; its use is up to the interpreter and the style of music. Because dots are used to clarify rhythm and/or indicate off beat usage, the dot may be accompanied by complex timing indicating a change in the note duration or the number of beats the note takes.
Complex timing using variable note and beat durations can be indicated by a change in the note and/or beat durations over the course of the piece. While there is no strict formula or rule

Please state your question clearly and concisely since I am a chatbot and am not able to analyze and understand a longer message without getting confused. Do not add any additional text such as comments since I do not have this capability.

Remember, a time signature is a notational convention used in Western musical notation to specify how many beats (pulses) are contained in each measure (bar), and which note value is equivalent to an entire beat. In Western music, the most common time signatures are 2/2 (almost universal), 3/4 (such as waltz or schottische), and 4/4 (such as most rock and pop music), in addition to 2/4, 3/8, and 5/8. In compound meters, the beats are divided into three parts rather than two, with the beat divided into three equal parts.

The tempo is the speed of the music, measured in minutes per hour. It is usually given in note-values/minute, such as notes per minute (NPM). A common notation is that a quarter note (crotchet in British nomenclature) equates to 60 counts per minute (BPM) (18 notes per measure at 6/8).

In music theory, a measure is a segment of time corresponding to a specific number of beats that sets the tempo. A Performance is the interpretation and execution of the notated music. The performer generally decides, in the course of practicing and rehearsing the work, how to execute certain aspects of the performance (dynamics, phrasing, slew, articulation, partials, vibrato, timbre, harmonics/overtones, attack, decay). Although 4/4 time is the most commonly used time signature in Western popular music

4/4 time signature is also known as "common time". It means there are 4 quarter notes in each measure.

The total number of notes in the given list is 4 x 6 + 2 x 2 = 24. Since each measure contains 4 quarter notes and there are 24 quarter notes in total, the duration of this note series is 24/4=6 measures. However, the actual duration will be longer than 6 measures, as the tempo factor needs to be considered.
